question: Prove that the Greatest Integer Function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ given by $f(x) = [x]$, is neither one-one nor onto, where $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.
solution:
$f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is given by,
$f(x) = [x]$

It is seen that $f(1.2) = [1.2] = 1$, $f(1.9) = [1.9] = 1$.

$\therefore f(1.2) = f(1.9)$, but $1.2 \neq 1.9$.

$\therefore f$ is not one-one.

Now, consider $0.7 \in \mathbb{R}$.

It is known that $f(x) = [x]$ is always an integer. Thus, there does not exist any element $x \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $f(x) = 0.7$.

$\therefore f$ is not onto.

Hence, the greatest integer function is neither one-one nor onto.
